M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212, § 3, which grants Superior Courts jurisdiction over civil actions for damages above $50,000.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Middlesex County.

**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.raw_text: **Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167 (1973)**
**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.proposition: The duty owed to business invitees is well established in Massachusetts law.
**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the general obligation of one who controls business premises toward patrons and cites prior Massachusetts cases, reflecting that this duty is settled law. The court treats the standard—due care to keep premises reasonably safe or warn of non-obvious dangers known or reasonably knowable to the defendant—as a well-established principle, then applies it to the facts. This directly supports the proposition that the duty owed to business invitees is well established in Massachusetts law.
**Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. A.relevant_excerpt: “1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. Rossley v. S. S. Kresge Co. 339 Mass. 654, 656. Coates v. First Natl. Stores Inc. 322 Mass. 563, 565. Vance v. Gould, 355 Mass. 104, 105.”

**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass.proposition: In **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 372 (2010)**, the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts held that property owners have an obligation to "prevent injury to lawful entrants caused by dangerous conditions on their property."
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that the natural/unnatural distinction is abolished and that property owners now owe to lawful visitors, for hazards from snow and ice, the same duty of reasonable care they owe for all other hazards. That duty is framed as an obligation to act reasonably to prevent injury to lawful entrants from dangerous conditions on their property. Thus the case directly supports the proposition that property owners must prevent injury to lawful entrants caused by dangerous conditions on their property.
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 695.proposition: The Defendant is liable under the principle of premises liability, as articulated in **Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 695 (1973)**, which held that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors.
**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 695.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case that abolished the invitee/licensee distinction and held that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The provided excerpt is from a concurrence discussing the treatment of trespassers and criticizing continued reliance on status categories, which is consistent with the majority’s move toward a general duty of reasonable care. Although the quoted passage does not itself restate the holding, the case as a whole supports the proposition that landowners owe a duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors.
**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 695.relevant_excerpt:
[Majority opinion summarized] The court in Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees and held that an occupier of land owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors.

From the concurrence: “The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.”

**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.raw_text: **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 781 (2007)**
**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.proposition: A landowner’s duty extends to conducting reasonable inspections and remedying hazards, as noted in **Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 781 (2007)**.
**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss a landowner’s duty of reasonable care and references Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343, which includes discovering conditions and protecting invitees. However, Sheehan is principally about modifying the *notice* requirement via the mode-of-operation approach, not about articulating a specific duty to conduct reasonable inspections and remedy hazards. The cited pages focus on foreseeability and mode of operation, not on an explicit rule that landowners must conduct reasonable inspections and remedy hazards, so using this case for that precise proposition overstates its holding.
**Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, I.relevant_excerpt: “A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if, but only if, he (a) knows or by the exercise of reasonable care would discover the condition… and (c) fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.… [I]t is necessary… to consider ‘whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that… an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred.’”

**Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 M.proposition: In **Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 841 (1987)**, the Court affirmed that a failure to maintain premises in a safe condition can result in liability for foreseeable injuries.
**Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 M.support_reasoning: The quoted concurring opinion addresses duty and foreseeability in the context of a gas station’s obligation to warn customers of risks from other drivers, and concludes there is no duty to warn because the risk is inherent and obvious. This cuts against, rather than affirms, a broad principle that failure to maintain premises in a safe condition results in liability for foreseeable injuries. The passage focuses on the absence of duty and proximate cause, not on imposing liability for failure to maintain safe premises.
**Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 M.relevant_excerpt: “The question is whether, as a matter of law, Arco’s failure to erect a sign warning customers to be on guard against other vehicles did not unreasonably increase the risk of injury caused by the improper operation of other vehicles on the premises. I agree with the court that the evidence did not present a jury question. … In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

**Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor,.proposition: The allegations in this Complaint are consistent with the standard of care established by cases such as **Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor, Inc., 390 Mass. 6, 11 (1983)**, where the Court found property owners liable for improperly stacked inventory.
**Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor,.support_reasoning: The case concerns a liquor store’s liability for negligently selling alcohol to a minor who later caused a fatal automobile accident. It addresses statutory duties, foreseeability, and proximate cause in the context of alcohol sales, not premises liability or the standard of care for stacking or maintaining inventory on property. There is no discussion of improperly stacked inventory or property owners’ liability for such conditions, so citing this case for that proposition is inaccurate.
**Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor,.relevant_excerpt: “The store asserts that liability extends to vendors of alcoholic beverages for injuries caused by their customers only when the sale of those beverages is to an intoxicated customer. We do not agree. It is the rule of this Commonwealth that negligence on the part of a seller or supplier of alcoholic beverages may be shown by a sale or the furnishing of those beverages to a minor, as well as to an inebriated person, as each is proscribed by statute.”

**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.raw_text: **Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 901-02 (1987)**
**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.proposition: Additionally, under **Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 901-02 (1987)**, a business owner can be liable when the foreseeable actions of third parties contribute to a hazardous condition.
**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that the restaurant had no duty because the incident—an out-of-control vehicle unintentionally entering the premises—was not reasonably foreseeable, and it distinguishes cases where proprietors were held liable. It emphasizes limits on foreseeability and rejects imposing liability for such third‑party conduct on these facts. Thus, it does not support the proposition that a business owner can be liable when foreseeable third‑party actions contribute to a hazard; rather, it finds the third‑party conduct here was not foreseeable and denies liability.
**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.relevant_excerpt: “The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons. … [T]here could be no reasonable difference of opinion as to the improbability of the incident which occurred.”

**M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Pursuant to **M.G.L. c. 231, § 85**, the comparative fault statute, the Plaintiff’s conduct was not negligent, and the Defendant bore exclusive responsibility for the unsafe conditions.
